Comments_List: I learned about theoretical aspects of Distributed computing.
Distributed system paradigms and foundational problems. How to reason about distributed processes sending messages asynchronously, or accessing shared memory asynchronously.

Strenghts: material is very interesting and good. 
Weaknesses: professor goes very fast in lecture. Not enough problem sets to enforce learning (when he gave them they were sufficiently rigorous, though).

Very interesting material. Misleadingly manageable in the first half. But too much content, gets way too difficult in the second half. You're either one of those grad students/undergrad geniuses who get most of everything, or you realize (too late) you're in over your head and you struggle to understand the most basic 20% of stuff. But you still learn a lot, and the expectations are actually not very high - that 20% is enough to scrape by/get a decent grade if you pore over the readings dilligently and go for office hours often enough.
Yes. Material is good and professor is entertaining.

Go for it if you have a credit/D to spare. Despite everyone (including the prof) saying that its really theoretical and only 1% is practically relevant to say web dev, its still nice to know you can intellectually categorize and deal with various constructs and components of distributed systems.
